description:
Engraulis encrasicolus, commonly known as the European anchovy, is a small pelagic fish species belonging to the family Engraulidae. It is found in the northeastern Atlantic Ocean, the Mediterranean Sea, and the Black Sea.

The European anchovy is a small, slender fish, typically reaching a maximum length of around 15 centimeters. It has a distinct pointed snout, large eyes, and a small, toothless mouth. The body is silvery-blue in color, with a translucent, greenish-blue back and silvery-white underside.

Engraulis encrasicolus is an important commercial and ecological species. It plays a crucial role in marine food webs, serving as a prey for various larger predatory fish, seabirds, and marine mammals. Anchovies are also a valuable resource for human consumption, being used in a variety of culinary dishes, as well as for the production of fish oil and fish meal.

The species is known for its ability to form large, dense schools, which can be targeted by commercial fisheries. The management and conservation of the European anchovy stock is an important consideration for fisheries and environmental authorities in the regions where it is found.
